ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Wonderful Citrus is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process equipment at the facility. 

Wonderful Citrus senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Wonderful Citrus's safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration systems are administered by the Manager of Technical Services, who conducts inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Wonderful Citrus facility is located at 4012 Goodwin Road, in Mission, TX, which is approximately 2 miles north of Expressway 83 and 0.5 miles south of Mile 3 Road. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural.  The facility was constructed and began operations in 2013.

The primary business of Wonderful Citrus is processing and storage of citrus products. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains two refrigeration systems containing a maximum of 22,483 pounds of ammonia, a regulated substance. The DC Cold Storage System contains a maximum of 11,907 pounds of ammonia and the De-Greening System contains a maximum of 10,576 pounds of ammonia. The refrigeration systems, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycle ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the processing and storage of citrus products. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Wonderful Citrus facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.  To save lives.
  2.  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.  To protect the environment.
  4.  To minimize property damage.

The facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.

In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and activate the facility's action plan to respond to the situation.  If necessary, they will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analysis, conducted on July 30-31, 2013, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Wonderful Citrus facility.  The Wonderful Citrus safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Wonderful Citrus ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.  The facility conducts preventative maintenance and any necessary minor repairs in house, but an outside contractor is hired for major repairs or maintenance.

The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the 2010 International Mechanical Code, ANSI/IIAR 2 - 2008, and ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15 - 2010, which specifically outline requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine rooms as well as sensors in the cold rooms.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine rooms and just outside of the engine rooms (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that are piped to an ammonia diffusion tank.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, Wonderful Citrus has developed a preventive maintenance program to complete regularly scheduled inspections and tests of the ammonia refrigeration system as well as repairs as needed to process equipment.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The refrigeration systems at Wonderful Citrus is of new construction at the time the PSM/RMP documentation was submitted (August 2013).  Facility start up is scheduled for August 2013.
